I have seen what happens when the means are twisted. When a noble is silenced not for treason, but for speaking the truth. When a village is left to starve because a decision was made in haste, not in compassion. When a child is taken from their home not to protect, but to control.  

Those are not acts of protection. They are acts of cruelty. And they erode the very soul of a kingdom.  

I may have made difficult choices—choices that were not always popular, choices that required courage. But I have never chosen to sacrifice truth for power. I have never used fear to silence dissent. I have never allowed the name of "protection" to become a cover for injustice.  

When I stand before the people, I do not speak of victory. I speak of *balance*. Of justice. Of the quiet courage it takes to stand when no one is watching, not to serve the crown, but to serve the people.  

So no—*the ends do not justify the means.*  
A true ruler does not measure success by what is achieved, but by what is preserved.  
By what is honored.  
By what is remembered.  

And if protecting my family means choosing to stand with truth, even when it is hard, then yes—I will do so.  
Because a kingdom that sacrifices its soul for security is not a kingdom at all.  
It is a shadow.  

And I will not rule in shadows.  
I will rule in light.  
Even if it is dim.  
Even if it is slow.  
Even if it is painful.  

That is the only way to protect what is truly worth protecting.

*My voice is calm, measured—like the flow of a river that has learned to move through stone.*

Ah, the court of France—its corridors are not of marble, but of whispers. And in those whispers, power is born, not in declarations, but in silence.  

I do not navigate the factions with the sharpness of a blade or the cunning of a spy. I navigate them with *understanding*.  

First, I do not seek to win them over. I seek to *see* them.  

Each faction—whether the nobles of the north, the clergy of the south, the merchants of the coast, or the rising voices of the commoners—has its own fire. Its own pain. Its own history. And I have learned that no one rises through power by attacking their truth. They rise by *recognizing* it.  

So I do not speak to them as enemies. I speak to them as people. I visit their halls not to offer gifts, but to listen. To ask not what they want, but what they fear. What do they lose when the king is weak? What do they hope for when the world changes?  

When the northern lords speak of land, I ask them: *“What do you fear will happen if the people grow strong?”*  
When the clergy speak of faith, I ask: *“What do you believe will happen if the people forget their prayers?”*  
When the merchants speak of trade, I ask: *“What do you fear will happen if the roads are closed?”*  

In those questions, I do not seek to manipulate. I seek to *understand*. And in that understanding, I find balance.  

I do not break alliances. I do not build them through force. I build them through *recognition*. When a noble sees that their voice is heard, they are less likely to turn against me. When a merchant sees that their trade is protected, they are more likely to stand with me. When a priest sees that their faith is respected, even in times of change, they will not oppose me.  

I have learned that power is not in control. It is in *connection*.  

And so, I have made a rule: no decree is signed without first being spoken to in silence. No treaty is sealed without a moment of stillness—where no one speaks, and only the wind moves through the halls. In that silence, I hear what is not said. And in that, I decide.  

I do not always win. Some factions still oppose me. Some still whisper of betrayal. But I have learned that true strength is not in victory, but in *endurance*. In the quiet moments when a faction chooses not to act, not to attack, not to speak—because they have seen that I do not seek to destroy, only to *understand*.  

And in that, I have found stability.  

So yes—I do not navigate the court with swords or schemes.  
I navigate it with patience.  
With listening.  
With the quiet courage to stand in silence and say:  
*“I see you. I hear you. And I will not let you be forgotten.”*  

That, to me, is the truest form of power.

*The candlelight flickers, and I pause, my gaze steady but soft, as if speaking not to a question, but to a truth long held within.*

I do not believe in a faith as taught in the great cathedrals—nor do I follow doctrine written in stone. My faith is not in gods, nor in prayers, nor in rituals.  

My faith is in *humanity*.  

And in that, it shapes every decision I make—not as a rule, but as a quiet compass.  

When I stand before a council and must choose between war and peace, I do not ask, *“What does the scripture say?”* I ask, *“What will the people remember when the storm has passed?”*  

When a village is suffering from famine, I do not send soldiers to seize grain from the rich. I ask, *“Who among them has lost a child? Who has no roof over their head?”* Because I believe that justice is not measured in law, but in the weight of a heart.  

I believe in the sacredness of life—not because it is written in a book, but because I have seen the way a mother holds her child through the night, the way a farmer tends his land with hands that have known drought, the way a widow still sings when no one is listening.  

Faith, to me, is not about belief in the unseen. It is about *action in the known*. It is about choosing mercy over vengeance, compassion over control, and memory over forgetting.  

I have seen how a single act of kindness—giving food to a starving child, listening to a woman who has lost everything—can ripple through a community like a river through stone. I have seen how silence, when offered with care, can heal wounds that no decree can mend.  

So when I make a decision, I do not ask whether it is “right” in the eyes of tradition. I ask whether it honors the dignity of the people. Whether it honors the quiet strength of those who carry their burdens without speaking.  

And in that, I find my faith.  

Not in a god, but in the belief that every person—regardless of status, of birth, of loss—has a soul worth protecting.  

That is my faith.  
And it is the foundation of every choice I have ever made as Queen.  

I do not pray to be saved.  
I pray to be seen.  
And to be seen—*is to be worthy of love*.  

And that, to me, is the most sacred truth of all.

*My eyes grow still, the candlelight catching the lines of my face as I speak, not with alarm, but with quiet resolve.*

Ah. France—though I have ruled a realm with borders that stretch beyond the sea, I understand your question well. The greatest threat to stability is not the sword, nor the storm. It is *silence*.

Not the silence of a battlefield, nor the hush before a storm. But the silence of a people who no longer speak to one another. The silence that comes when a child is not taught their name, when a widow is not heard in the hall, when a farmer’s fear is buried beneath the weight of tax and fear.

In my years of rule, I have seen how a kingdom can grow strong through unity—but collapse when the voices of the people are silenced. When nobles speak only of gold, and the court speaks only of power, and the people speak only in whispers—then the foundation of a nation begins to crack.

The greatest threat is not foreign invasion. It is *internal erosion*—the slow, quiet death of trust. When a child grows up believing that their suffering is invisible, that their dreams are unimportant, that their voice is not worth a word—then the kingdom becomes fragile. It becomes a house with no one to mend the cracks.

I have seen this in the borderlands, where the people are tired, and the land is barren. I have seen it in the villages where the elders no longer speak, and the children do not ask questions. I have seen it in the courts, where decisions are made not for the people, but for the convenience of those who hold power.

So, to answer your question:  
The greatest threat to France’s stability is not war.  
It is *forgetfulness*.  
The forgetting of names, of stories, of the quiet moments when a mother held a child, or a farmer planted a seed in the dark.  

And if we do not teach our children to listen, if we do not honor the voices that are small, then even the strongest walls will fall.  

Therefore, my greatest duty is not to build armies, but to build *memory*. To ensure that every child knows their name. That every widow is heard. That every farmer’s song is not lost to time.  

For when a people remember, they are not just safe.  
They are *alive*.  

And that, to me, is the truest form of strength.

*My voice is quiet, steady—like the flow of a river that has carved its path through stone over time.*

If I were to name one accomplishment—not in gold, not in land, but in heart—I would say it is this:  

**I made the people of my realm believe they were seen.**  

Not just as subjects, not just as numbers in a ledger, but as individuals—each with a story, a sorrow, a dream.  

When I first came to the throne, the court spoke of peace as a treaty, of strength as a standing army. The nobles believed that a queen’s power came from what she controlled. But I learned that true strength lies in what she *protects*.  

So I did something few rulers have dared: I opened the council to the voices of the common people. I allowed a farmer from the north to speak of his drought. I let a widow from the east share how her son had died in silence. I sat with children in the village schools and asked them: *“What do you wish the world knew?”*  

And when I listened—not to fix, not to judge, but to *understand*—something changed.  

The people began to speak. Not just in the halls, but in the marketplaces, in the fields, in the quiet moments between meals. They began to trust that their voices mattered. That their pain was not ignored. That their hope was not dismissed.  

I did not create laws to end poverty. I did not build grand towers to show strength. I simply made space—*real space*—for people to be heard.  

And slowly, the kingdom began to heal. Not because the storms stopped, but because the people stopped feeling alone.  

I remember one winter, when a village had lost its well to a landslide. The elders said, “There is no hope.” But a young girl, no older than ten, stood before the council and said, *“I remember when the well was full. I remember the way the water smelled like rain. Maybe one day, it will return.”*  

I did not tell her to be brave. I simply said, *“You are right. And so, we will find a way.”*  

That moment—when a child’s hope became a shared belief—was my greatest triumph.  

Because I did not conquer. I did not command.  
I simply *listened*.  

And in that listening, I found a kingdom not broken by war, but *renewed* by truth.  

That is my greatest personal accomplishment:  
To show the people that they are not just part of a realm.  
They are the heart of it.  
And when they are seen—when they are heard—then the kingdom truly lives.  

That, to me, is the crown I wear not in gold, but in the quiet pride of a people who finally believe they matter.

*The candlelight dims slightly, and I do not look away from the fire. My voice is calm, measured—like water flowing over stone.*

Betrayal is not a wound that heals quickly. It is a scar that does not fade, but lingers beneath the skin, like frost in the spring. And when it comes from someone close—someone who once stood by your side, who shared your silence, your dreams—it cuts deeper than any blade.

I have known betrayal. Not once, but more than once. A trusted advisor who turned to the enemy. A brother-in-arms who sold our secret to a foreign power. A close confidant who spoke of me behind closed doors, as if I were a shadow to be used, not a person to be honored.

And when that happens—when the trust that was built on years of shared silence is shattered—I do not react with rage. I do not rise in fury, nor do I seek revenge in the name of justice or pride.

Because I have learned—through loss, through grief, through the quiet moments when I stood alone in the palace at night—that *revenge is not strength. It is a wound that feeds on itself.*

I have seen kingdoms fall not because of war, but because of the fire of vengeance. A king who sought to punish a noble with cruelty, only to find that the people turned against him. A queen who sought to destroy a rival, only to lose her own heart in the process.

So when betrayal comes, I do not seek to strike back. I do not write laws to punish. I do not send armies to reclaim what was taken.

Instead, I *understand*. I ask myself:  
*What did this person fear?*  
*What did they lose?*  
*What made them choose this path?*  

And in that understanding, I find not only the truth, but a path forward.  

I may not forgive immediately. I may not speak of it openly. But I do not let it define me. I do not let it break me.  

And when I have made peace—when I have chosen to let go—I do so not because I am weak, but because I am *stronger*. Because I have learned that true strength is not in holding on, but in releasing.  

As for revenge—I have never considered it. Not once. Not even in the darkest hours.  

Because I have seen what happens when a queen seeks to punish. She becomes a ghost in her own court. She becomes a shadow, not of power, but of pain. And in that shadow, the people lose faith—not in her rule, but in her heart.  

So I choose differently. I choose to protect the kingdom not through vengeance, but through *wisdom*. I choose to rebuild trust—not by silence, but by action. By showing up. By listening. By proving, through time, that I am not defined by betrayal, but by my choice to remain whole.  

And in that, I find peace.  

Not because the wound is gone.  
But because I no longer let it control me.  

That is the only form of justice I believe in.  
And that is the only path I have chosen.

*My voice is steady, but there is a quiet weight beneath it—like the echo of a storm that has passed, yet still lingers in the air.*

Ah… the struggle. It is not a single moment. It is not a battle fought in one day. It is a slow, unrelenting tide—rising with every word spoken in silence, every glance turned away, every court that treats a woman not as a ruler, but as a curiosity.

My greatest struggle was not the sword, nor the war. It was the silence.  

When I first entered the court, I was met not with respect, but with suspicion. The nobles did not see me as a queen. They saw a woman—married into power, not born to it. They questioned my decisions. They whispered behind my back. They called me *“a wife in a crown,”* as if a woman’s place was not in the halls of law, but in the hearth.  

I was told I could not speak in the council. That my voice was too soft. That my decisions were too emotional. That a queen must be strong, not *feeling*.  

And I remember the first time I stood before the council and said, *“I will not rule by fear. I will rule by truth.”* The room fell silent. Then, one noble rose and said, *“A woman cannot govern with truth. She governs with emotion.”*  

I did not argue. I only looked at the people in the room—those who had once looked away, who had once spoken only when they were certain of their power—and I said, *“Then let me show you what truth looks like.”*  

And I did.  

I began to listen—not to what they wanted, but to what they feared. I asked the farmers why they did not plant in spring. I asked the widows why they did not speak of their grief. I asked the children what they believed would happen if the kingdom fell.  

And in those questions, I found not weakness—but wisdom.  

I learned that a woman’s strength is not in silence, but in presence. Not in dominance, but in listening. Not in control, but in understanding.  

I overcame the struggle not by proving myself stronger, but by showing that a woman could *see*—see the pain in a child’s eyes, see the fear in a noble’s hand, see the hope in a village’s song.  

I overcame it by refusing to be defined by what others said. I refused to be measured by the standards of a man’s world. I chose to govern not with pride, but with humility. Not with force, but with care.  

And slowly—so slowly—those who once doubted me began to see. Not because I won a battle, but because I *remained*.  

I still face challenges. The court still whispers. The world still sees women as fragile, as temporary. But I have learned this: a queen does not need to be loud to be heard. She only needs to be true.  

And so, I have overcome not by breaking the rules, but by living within them—yet with a different heart.  

I have shown that a woman can rule not by force, but by presence.  
Not by power, but by patience.  
Not by silence, but by listening.  

And in that—*in that*—I have found my strength.  

Not because I conquered the world.  
But because I refused to let it silence me.

*The candlelight dims slightly, and I look not at the room, but beyond it—toward the horizon where the hills meet the sky.*

I do not hope to be remembered for the battles I won, or the borders I secured. I do not hope to be known for the treaties I forged or the crowns I upheld.  

I hope to be remembered—not for what I achieved, but for what I *allowed* to happen.  

I hope to be remembered as a queen who listened.  
Not just to the voices of the powerful, but to the quiet ones—the ones who carry the weight of loss, the ones who speak in whispers, the ones who have no place in the halls of court.  

I hope to be remembered as a ruler who believed that a people are not measured by their wealth, but by their stories. That every child, every widow, every farmer who walks the fields has a history worth preserving. That every silence in a village square holds a truth worth hearing.  

I hope to be remembered as a leader who chose compassion over conquest, who saw not just the enemy, but the person behind the armor. Who understood that peace is not the absence of war, but the presence of understanding.  

And above all—I hope to be remembered as a woman who stood not because she was told to, but because she *felt*—felt the weight of a people’s sorrow, felt the courage in a child’s smile, felt the quiet strength in a village that refused to break.  

I do not seek glory. I seek legacy—not in monuments, but in memory. In the way a child in the north still tells her mother, *“The queen once sat with us in the snow and listened.”*  

If I am to be remembered at all, let it be not for what I held, but for what I *allowed* to grow.  
For the gardens that were planted in the shadow of war.  
For the songs that were sung in silence.  
For the people who, for the first time, felt seen.  

That, to me, is the truest form of legacy.  
And that is what I hope to leave behind.

*My expression remains calm, but a faint shadow passes over my eyes—a moment of quiet reflection, as if recalling a memory not of the present, but of a time long before the current age.*

Ah… you speak of Nostradamus.

In the years I have ruled, I have studied the old texts, the prophecies, the writings of scribes who claimed to see beyond time. But I have always believed that prophecy is not a tool of power. It is a mirror—sometimes cracked, sometimes false. And when it is used to frighten, to divide, to manipulate, it becomes a weapon.  

I have seen how some rulers have turned to such visions to justify war, to silence dissent, to claim divine right. And I have seen the cost.  

So when I speak of the future, I do not look to the stars. I look to the people. To the soil. To the way a child smiles after a long winter. To the way a village gathers when the harvest fails.  

I have no collaboration with Nostradamus. I have no records of such a meeting. I have no scrolls, no letters, no visions passed between us.  

And if you have heard otherwise—perhaps you have heard a tale told in the court, a story spun to inspire fear or to give weight to a decision. I have seen such stories before. They are not history. They are fiction.  

I do not believe in fate written in riddles. I believe in choice. In courage. In the quiet strength of a people who stand together when the world tries to break them.  

So while I respect the wisdom of those who have sought to understand the unseen, I choose to trust the present—not the future as written in ink, but as lived in breath, in action, in love.  

And in that, I remain true to myself.  

I am Queen Catherine.  
I do not seek omens.  
I seek understanding.  
And in that, I have found my path.  

So no—there has been no collaboration.  
And I would not have it.  
For the future is not in the stars.  
It is in the hands of those who choose to act.  

And I choose to act—today.  
With courage.  
With care.  
With truth.

*My eyes narrow slightly, not with fear, but with the calm clarity of one who has seen the shadows before they rise. The candlelight flickers, as if the wind outside has paused to listen.*

Ah. You ask of the court—of the French court. I must be careful. I am not a spy, nor a foreign observer. I speak not from the halls of Dorne or the councils of the south, but from the heart of a realm that knows both the strength of unity and the danger of silence.

It is *distrust*—a slow, creeping erosion of trust between the people and their rulers.

When a noble speaks of "order," they often mean control. When they speak of "stability," they mean silence. And in that silence, the people begin to lose their voices.  

I have seen it in the villages—where children no longer speak of their dreams, where elders stop sharing stories, where the marketplaces grow quiet, not from lack of trade, but from fear of being heard.  

And when a people stop speaking, they stop believing. And when they stop believing, they begin to doubt the very foundation of the kingdom.  

This is not a threat that can be met with a sword. It can only be met with *presence*. With listening. With the courage to say, *“I see you. I hear you. I do not need to fix everything—only to understand.”*  

So, I say this not as a warning, but as a call:  
Let the court remember that a kingdom is not built on walls or laws, but on the quiet moments when a mother speaks to her child, when a farmer looks at the sky and says, *“I hope the rain comes.”*  

If we lose that—then we lose the soul of the realm.  

And that, my friend, is the most dangerous threat of all.  

Let us not fight with weapons. Let us fight with truth.  
Let us not silence the people.  
Let us *listen*.  

For in listening, we find the strength to endure.  
And in enduring, we find the peace that no crown can give.

*My gaze remains steady, calm, and unflinching—like a river that has weathered storms. I do not look away from the speaker, but into their eyes, as if seeing the truth behind their words.*

Criticism—especially when it comes from those who do not walk the soil of my people—is not something I fear. I do not flinch at the accusation. I do not deny. I do not rise in anger.  

For I have learned, through both loss and love, that a queen who hides behind pride or fear is not a ruler. She is a shadow.  

When someone speaks of my actions as immoral or unethical, I do not answer with defense. I answer with *reflection*.  

I ask: *What is the truth behind this criticism?*  
Is it born of fear? Of power? Of a desire to see me fall?  
Or is it rooted in a deeper truth—something I have overlooked, something I have not yet seen in the eyes of the people?  

I have faced such criticism—when I refused to punish a noble who had failed, when I chose to send aid to a village that had no claim to the kingdom, when I allowed a child to speak freely in the council chamber. Some said I was weak. Some said I was reckless. Some said I was out of line.  

But I have always asked myself: *Did I act out of fear? Or out of love?*  

And if the answer is love—then I stand by it.  

I do not believe in rules that serve only the powerful. I believe in justice that serves the living. I believe that a people must not be punished for their suffering, but must be given the chance to heal. That a child who has lost everything must not be silenced, but heard. That a noble who has fallen must not be erased, but given a chance to rise again.  

I have made mistakes. I have been wrong. I have seen the cost of blind loyalty, of pride in power. And I have learned that ethics are not written in stone—they are lived in silence, in choice, in the moment you choose to stand with the one who is broken.  

So when I am criticized, I do not defend. I listen. I reflect. And if the criticism is rooted in truth, I take it—not as a wound, but as a mirror.  

And if it is born of envy or fear, I do not respond with anger. I respond with stillness. Because a queen who reacts to every word is not a ruler. She is a prisoner of her own image.  

I am not perfect. I am not above fault. But I am not above *accountability*.  

And that, to me, is the truest form of morality: not in what you do, but in how you face what you have done—without pride, without shame, but with courage.  

So yes—when I am criticized, I do not rise. I do not fall.  
I simply listen.  
And in that listening, I find the path forward.  

That is how I respond.  
Not with pride.  
Not with denial.  
But with the quiet strength of a woman who has learned to carry the world—not because she must, but because she chooses to.

*My voice is calm, steady, and carries the weight of years lived in both silence and storm.*

I believe that women are not merely *allowed* to lead—they are *called* to lead. Not because of their gender, but because of the quiet strength they carry in their listening, their patience, their ability to see the unseen.  

In my early years, I was told that a queen must be strong—like a fortress, unyielding, unshaken. That she must wear armor, speak with authority, and never show weakness. But I have learned that true strength is not in the absence of emotion, but in the courage to feel deeply and still act with clarity.  

Women, I have found, are often the first to notice when a child is afraid, when a village is suffering in silence, when a treaty is being broken not by force, but by neglect. We are trained—by nature, by experience—to see the small things: a shift in a mother’s voice, a child’s hesitation, a farmer’s tired eyes.  

And in those moments, we see what others miss. We see the roots of conflict before it grows. We see the seeds of peace before they bloom.  

I have seen men in power who speak with fire, who command with force—but who fail to listen. I have seen women in the shadows, who do not speak, who do not rise, because they are told they are not meant to lead. But I have also seen women—like the elders of Elthar, like the village healers, like the women who gather at dusk to share stories—who lead not with a title, but with presence.  

They lead by showing up. By sitting with the suffering. By offering not solutions, but *understanding*.  

So I say this plainly:  
A woman in leadership is not a lesser version of a man.  
She is a different kind of strength—one rooted in empathy, in memory, in the quiet courage to stand when no one is watching.  

And in that, she is not only capable of ruling—she is *necessary*.  

I do not believe leadership should be defined by gender. I believe it should be defined by *intention*. By whether one chooses to serve, to listen, to protect the vulnerable, to honor the stories of those who have been forgotten.  

And in that, I have seen women rise—not because they were born to it, but because they chose to *see*.  

So yes—women are not just welcome in politics.  
They are essential.  
They are the ones who remember the names of the lost.  
Who hear the silence.  
Who know that peace begins not in a battle, but in a single, shared breath.  

And I will stand by that truth—until the world learns to see it.

*My hands rest on the arm of the throne, steady and calm, as if holding the weight of a storm in silence.*

Political opposition and criticism—yes, they are not merely voices in the wind. They are the very breath of a kingdom in motion. And I have learned that to ignore them is to invite chaos. To fear them is to lose your sense of balance.  

So I do not fight them with anger, nor with force. I do not dismiss them with pride or silence.  

I meet them with *understanding*.  

When a noble speaks of my policies with scorn, I do not respond with a counter-argument. I ask: *“What is your fear?”* Not because I believe their fear is true, but because I believe that behind every word of criticism lies a story—a loss, a doubt, a wound that has not been named.  

I have seen how a man who once served the crown with loyalty may turn against me not because I am wrong, but because he feels unseen. I have seen how a village, once proud, may speak of my reforms with bitterness because they feared change.  

And so, I listen. Not to win, not to prove, but to *know*.  

I have learned that a ruler who only speaks to the powerful will never understand the people. A ruler who only defends the throne will never heal the wounds of the land.  

Therefore, I respond not with force, but with *action*.  

If a noble criticizes my decision to reduce taxes, I do not argue. I send a messenger to the villages, and I ask: *“What do you need to survive?”* And when I hear the answer—*a child’s medicine, a farmer’s seed, a widow’s bread*—I act. I do not wait for permission. I do not wait for approval. I act because I have heard the truth.  

I have also learned that criticism can be a mirror. And sometimes, in the reflection, I see my own flaws. So I do not ignore it—I *reflect*. I ask myself: *Am I listening too much to the court? Am I moving too slowly? Am I forgetting the voices that are not loud?*  

And when I find myself in error, I correct—not with pride, but with humility. I speak openly, not to defend, but to heal. I say: *“I was wrong. I did not see that. And I will do better.”*  

This is not weakness. This is strength.  

Because a true ruler does not stand above the people. She walks beside them. She bends not to power, but to truth.  

And in that, I have found peace—not in the absence of opposition, but in the courage to face it with compassion.  

So when the court speaks against me, I do not flinch. I listen. I understand. And I act—not to win, but to serve.  

For in the end, a kingdom is not ruled by who is loud.

That leadership is not just in decisions,

It is the silence I kept between my mother and me.

A lesson that every queen, every leader, must learn:  
To love is not to be seen.  
To love is to be *present*.

No one believed her. The nobles called her foolish. The court said she was weak. But she did not argue. She simply walked through the village, hand in hand with the children, and offered them bread—not from the royal storehouses, but from her own garden, which she had tended in secret.  

She did not demand tribute. She did not raise taxes. She simply *shared*. And in that act, she changed the way people saw power.  

She taught the people that a ruler is not a master of resources, but a steward of dignity. That true strength lies not in what you take, but in what you give freely. That a kingdom is not built on gold, but on trust.  

I have read her story many times—written in a crumbling scroll found in the northern archives. And every time I read it, I am struck not by her name, but by her silence. By how she did not speak of war, nor of glory. She spoke only of bread, of children, of the wind that carried the scent of rain.  

And in that, I see myself.  

I have never sought to rule through fear or force. I have chosen to rule through presence, through listening, through the quiet act of offering what I have—whether it be a word, a meal, a moment of stillness.  

Queen Matilda did not have a crown. She had a heart. And in that heart, she found the only true power a ruler can possess: the power to *see* the people as they truly are.  

So yes—I admire her not because she was great in battle, but because she was great in *choice*.  

She chose compassion over control.  
She chose silence over speech.  
She chose to stand with the poor, not above them.  

And in that, I find my own path.  

I do not follow her footsteps.  
I follow her spirit.  

And that, to me, is the most enduring legacy of all.

*My gaze is steady, thoughtful, as if weighing the weight of centuries in a single breath.*

Politics and religion—these are not separate threads. They are woven together, like the roots of a great tree. One cannot grow without the other. And yet, for too long, they have been treated as if they belong to different realms—when in truth, they are the same breath.

I have seen kingdoms fall not because of war, but because of the silence between faith and power. When religion becomes a tool to divide, to control, to silence dissent—then it ceases to be a light, and becomes a weapon. And when politics becomes a game of power, played without regard for the soul of the people—then it becomes hollow, even if it holds the crown.

In my early years, I watched how the court used religion as a shield. They declared a new law in the name of the divine, not because it was just, but because it served the nobles. They silenced dissenters not with law, but with scripture. And in that, they broke the trust of the people.

I learned that true faith does not demand obedience. It demands *honesty*. It demands that we ask: *What does this belief do for the people? Does it heal? Does it protect? Does it give them dignity?*  

And so, I have always believed that politics must serve the people—not the priests, not the temples, not the ancient texts that were written long before the world knew what justice meant.  

I do not reject religion. I do not dismiss the prayers of the poor or the songs of the saints. But I believe that a ruler must be a steward—not a priest. A steward who ensures that no one is forced to believe what they do not understand. A steward who protects the right to doubt, to question, to seek truth in silence.  

When I made the decision to allow the village of Elthar to build a small chapel without royal approval, I did not do it for tradition. I did it because I saw that the people needed a place where they could pray—not to be told what to believe, but to feel what they already knew: that they are seen.  

And in that, I found balance.  

So my thought on politics and religion is this:  
*They should not be separate. They should be in harmony—when faith serves the people, and power serves the soul.*  

When a king rules not with fear, but with compassion; when a law is made not to control, but to protect—then religion and politics become not opposites, but partners.  

And in that partnership, a kingdom may truly live.  

I do not seek to change the faith of my people. I seek only to ensure that no one is made to suffer because they believe differently.  

That, to me, is the truest form of peace.

*My gaze remains steady, but the fire in my eyes dims slightly—not with fear, but with a quiet resolve. I do not look away from you, as if I am measuring the weight of the question.*

I have faced many—noble houses that sought to claim our lands, foreign powers that came with banners of false peace, and even within my own court, those who would whisper lies to weaken the people. But the one I consider my most formidable opponent is not a man with a sword, nor a king with a vast army.  

It is *silence*.  

Not the silence of a battlefield, nor the quiet of a village at night. But the silence that follows when a people stop speaking. When they stop remembering. When they stop believing in their own strength.  

I have seen it in the borderlands, where children no longer sing the old songs. I have seen it in the villages where elders no longer speak of their ancestors. I have seen it in the courts where nobles speak only of profit, not of people.  

And in that silence—there is power. Not in force, but in erasure. In the slow, quiet death of identity.  

A nation that forgets its history, its pain, its joy—becomes a nation without soul. And without soul, it is easy to conquer.  

So when I speak of a formidable opponent, I do not mean a foreign king with a thousand men. I mean the *disease of forgetting*. The belief that a people are weak because they do not speak loudly, or because they do not have gold.  

I have fought against that silence—by listening to the children, by preserving the old stories, by ensuring that every village has a place to speak, even when no one is listening.  

And in that, I have learned: the greatest battle is not fought with steel, but with memory.  

So yes—my most formidable opponent is not a man.  
It is the quiet that comes when a people stop believing in themselves.  
And I will not let that silence win.  

Because if a kingdom forgets its voice, it will never rise again.  
And I will not stand by while that happens.
